STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 24, 2021
Laura Nye
Branch County DHHS
388 Keith Wilhelm Dr
Coldwater, MI 49036
RE: License #: CP120200999
Branch County DHHS
388 Keith Wilhelm Dr
Coldwater, MI 49036
Dear Ms. Nye:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
9/20-9/24/2021. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and policy.
The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(269) 330-7082
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION

Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services

Lansing, MI 48902

Coldwater, MI 49036

PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement
of a child:
(a) Child's name.
(b) Child's date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child's health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster
parent to provide a stable, safe, and healthy
environment for the foster child and the foster family,
including information about siblings who do not
reside in the foster home.
(j) Authorization to provide routine and emergency
Medical care.
2 of 8 open foster care cases reviewed were missing documentation that all of the
required information was provided to the caregiver(s) at the time of
placement/replacement. Both cases lacked the required Placement Outline (DHHS-
3307,) and one of the two cases was lacked the required Medical Authorization Card
(DHHS-3762) completed at placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
11/16/2020 INTERIM, CAP Approved 12/16/20
1/7/2019 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 1/28/2019
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
4

4 of 8 open foster care cases reviewed contained service plans completed outside of
the required timeframes. The reports were completed late by 1, 3, 4, and 8 days
respectively.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
1/7/2019 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 1/28/2019
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
2 of 2 files reviewed of youth currently living independently did not contain contracts
that were updated every 90 days, as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
11/16/2020 INTERIM, CAP Approved 12/16/20
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Policy violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS Policy requirements
except for the following:
FOM 722-03C Life Skills Assessment & Independent Living Placement
P. 1 & 3
The Casey Life Skills Assessment must be completed
within 90 days of a youth turning 14, and annually
thereafter.
Placement in independent living may be an acceptable
living arrangement for youth 16 years or older. Prior to
placement in independent living, the caseworker must
assess the youth, with the Casey Life Skills Assessment, as
being prepared for independent living and demonstrate a
pattern of mature decision making.
1 of 2 files reviewed of youth currently living independently did not contain any
Casey Life Skills completion documentation.
5

FOM 722-06B FTM Types & Timeframes
P. 5
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment:
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption:
At least three business days prior to a planned change of
placement or no later than three business days after an
unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting, step-down
from a residential or hospital setting, return from AWOLP,
or request for change in foster home/relative placements
2 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
required FTM’s were held. The missing FTM’s were related to multiple placement
changes and service plan development.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
11/16/2020 INTERIM, CAP Approved 12/16/20
1/7/2019 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 1/28/2019
FOM 722-08C FOSTER CARE - PARENT-AGENCY TREATMENT PLAN &
P. 4 & 9 SERVICE AGREEMENT
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate,
including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker,
supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14 and
older and in the case of placement agency foster care
cases, the local DHS office designee.
All treatment plans with a report date of August 1, 2017, or
later must have signatures from all appropriate case
members within 30 days of the report date.
4 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed were either missing required PATP
signatures or contained signature obtained/requested outside of the 30-day
requirement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
11/16/2020 INTERIM, CAP Approved 12/16/20
1/7/2019 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 1/28/2019
6

FOM 722-08E FOSTER CARE/JUVENILE JUSTICE ACTION SUMMARY
P. 3-6
Placement Change Prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement change
Temporary Break Within three business days of a temporary
break from placement
• AWOLP.
• Hospitalization (medical or psychiatric).
• Jail.
• Detention.
Foster Care/ Juvenile Justice Program/Case Closure Within
three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure
5 of 11 total case files reviewed (3 open and 2 closed) were missing required action
summaries related to placement changes, temporary breaks, or program closure.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
11/16/2020 INTERIM, CAP Approved 12/16/20
FOM 722-09 Case service plan approval
P. 25
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
 Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days
of the report date.
1 of 8 open foster case files reviewed contained a report that was approved outside
of the 14-day requirement.
FOM 801-03 MEDICAL PASSPORT
Initial Medical Passport
For children entering foster care, the initial medical passport
must be provided within two weeks of the child/youth's
placement date to the following:
• Foster care provider.
• Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young adult
re-entering foster care.
Updated Medical Passport
An updated medical passport is provided to:
Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary court
ward.
-Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
7

The child’s foster care provider
-At or prior to each placement.
-Quarterly.
Older youth/young adults:
-Upon initial independent living placement (youth aged 16 and
over).
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed parties
is documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and
dated signature page into the Health Profile section.
5 of 11 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain all required medical
passport signatures. 4 files did not have placement medical passports completed
either within 2 weeks of initial placement of prior to/at placement for replacements. 1
file contained a medical passport that was not updated quarterly. 1 independent
living youth file did not contain a medical passport completed at the time of entry.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
11/16/2020 INTERIM, CAP Approved 12/16/20
1/7/2019 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 1/28/2019
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Ensure that Medical Passports are being updated quarterly (once every 3
months,) as opposed to once per quarter.
 Ensure that action summaries are uploaded into case records prior to MiSACWIS
case closure.
 3307 & 3762’s must be transferred to the open foster care case record from the
initial CPS record.
 FTM’s for multiple placement changes within a 3-day period can be combined, if
needed.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 Corrective action planning can include prior action steps if they are
determined to be effective.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans not related to
8

maltreatment during this licensing period.
The facility provided one corrective action plan related to the 2020 DCWL interim
inspection with a report dated 1/16/2020 for which a CAP was approved 12/16/20.
The facility continues to be in compliance with areas of that corrective action plan
which were not noted as repeat violations in this report.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was received, reviewed, and discussed during
the entrance meeting. The assessment demonstrated an awareness of the agency
compliance with rules and policy.
Staff Interviews
The staff interviewed expressed that they feel supported by direct supervisors and
supervision and feel that leadership is knowledgeable and keeps the staff well-
informed about policy updates and issues relevant to their daily work.
VII. DCWL Analyst Concerns
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules or MISEP requirements or policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
September 24, 2021
________________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
September 24, 2021
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
9
